content.webTitle: Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and kids play half-time kick-to-kick: Community Cup turns 25

fields.headline: Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and kids play half-time kick-to-kick: Community Cup turns 25
fields.bodyText: With their red-and-yellow pom-poms, cheerleader skirts, garish makeup and hair in bunches akimbo, anyone ought to find the Rockdogs cheer squad a glorious sight. But for Millie Negro, just five in 1995, they were out of this world. As the footy players tore up the pitch at that early Community Cup match, she trailed around the strange ladies in awe. Negro has been attending the annual amateur charity match, beloved by Melburnians into music and Australian rules footy alike, since its inception in 1993. That’s thanks to her dad, the musician and cartoonist Fred Negro, serving as the captain of the Espy Rockdogs for years. (It was a fitting appointment, given that he’s been part of the fabric of legendary St Kilda rock venue the Esplanade Hotel for even longer.) In the cup’s earliest incarnation, the Rockdogs were pitted against other Melbourne venues in a casual kick-about. Then in 1997 founder Jason Evans and James Young – now owner of Cherry Bar, then program manager at community radio station 3RRR – decided to form a larger music industry event for charity, which back then was St Kilda’s Sacred Heart Mission. The Espy Rockdogs would be made up of musicians. A new team, the Megahertz, was put together of folk from 3RRR and another Melbourne community radio station, PBS. Ever since, it’s been an annual highlight of any music and footy fan’s social calendar. “A stand-out moment was in 2010,” says Negro. “A few hairy, tatted-up, trucker-looking blokes in local bands, one being my godfather Phil Grinder [of punk rock band X], dressed as cheerleaders. They got up on stage while the Living End were playing and danced as go-go girls.” Another year, Dan Sultan was captain of the Rockdogs. By then Negro was a young woman and had realised her childhood dream by joining the cheer squad. “We had a cheer that went, ‘Dan, Dan, he’s our man, if he can’t do it, no one can,’ ” she says. At the 25th Community Cup on 23 June, Sultan will be back, this time to perform with special guest Paul Kelly. Odds are the set will involve a cover of Kelly and Kev Carmody’s From Little Things Big Things Grow, since that’s the theme this year. Other sets will come from Magic Dirt, RVG, Harvey Sutherland and Baker Boy, and kids’ entertainment from The Burnt Sausages. While the atmosphere is invariably raucous, Negro says it’s always been a fun family outing. “There were loads of other kids to run around with,” she says. “At half-time everyone was allowed on the field to kick footies with their friends and families after laughing at the traditional streaker.” Actually that’s a tradition lost since the event moved from Elsternwick to Abbotsford’s Victoria Park in 2017. The local police north of the river weren’t au fait with such hijinks and moved in to charge streakers with indecency. But despite morphing into a well-oiled machine, the Community Cup remains old school, something that music promoter James Young thinks holds huge appeal to those nostalgic for footy games of yore. He and his wife, Miranda, have been taking their kids Max, Archie and Somer (now 22, 20 and 18) since they were born. “You’re going back to grassroots – football played on suburban grounds where you stand with a beer in your hand,” he says. “It was heartbreaking when the AFL stopped letting kids on the field after the game. One of the great things about the Community Cup is they let the punters on the ground, not just after the game but in the breaks. My boys would have their hands on the fence just waiting for the final whistle so they could go and kick the ball. It’s a great sound, 100 people kicking footballs at the same time.” Over the years, Young has been a captain, coach and umpire, but now he’s happy to be a punter. As he points out, the game has been reduced from 25-minute quarters to 15 minutes. “The game is almost the least interesting aspect,” he says. “One year Spiderbait played at half-time. Kram had been playing for the Rockdogs, so he ran off the field and got behind the drums still wearing his footy boots.” Tim Rogers, who’s playing for the Rockdogs this year, doesn’t agree that the footy takes second stage to the entertainment. “There are some incredibly skilled footballers, men and women, in both teams and I’m agog at what they can do,” he says. “It’s not a level playing field, so there are times when it’s ugly and scrappy, and times when it’s a beautiful game to watch. I like that mix; I think that’s the way it should be. When it’s all perfect and everyone’s muscular, that just seems too much like CGI to me.” Since the early 2000s, Tim Rogers has been a coach, player and umpire, before taking a hiatus in which he became more involved in the interstate events – Perth, Adelaide, Sydney, Hobart and Brisbane have all hosted Community Cup events. “I got the call-up to play again,” he says. “I think they wanted an elderly citizen as some kind of example of how to grow old disgracefully. I also wanted to play well for my dad because he’s unwell and I thought it might give him a bit of a gee-up.” Rogers’ father was an umpire for what was then the Victorian Football Association, before the family moved to Kalgoorlie in Western Australia, where he did the same for the Goldfields Football League. “I used to follow him round every week and it’s where I got my knowledge of bad language,” Rogers says. “My dad was an excellent footy player, right up there skill-wise. As an umpire he was, for a big guy, very taciturn and measured, and I got a lot from the power of silence, so I’m going to keep trying to learn from that.” In 2018, 10,000 people attended the Community Cup, raising $170,000 for Reclink, a provider of sports and arts programs to disadvantaged Australians. It’s a hands-on approach Rogers wholly approves of. “If people are in a bad way, just getting them part of a team, it’s not necessarily a life changer but gee, it can get you in a much better frame of mind,” he says. “I’m a living example of that. So I’ll keep contributing. I’ll make the sandwiches and Bovril next year, how about that?” • The 25th Reclink Community Cup is on at Victoria Park in Abbotsford, Melbourne, on Sunday 23 June
